description:
We're running Openstack Essex (openstack-nova-2012.1-7.el6.noarch) on Centos 6.3. We use VLANs (nova.network.manager.VlanManager) to separete the tenants from each other.

We noticed that the nova-network host that acts as a gateway for the virtual machines bridges all traffic between the VLANs. This means that any tenant has access to any other tenant's network, and other internal networks that happen to be available. It seems that the problems are these firewall rules

-A nova-network-FORWARD -i br100 -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -o br100 -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -d 192.168.100.2/32 -p udp -m udp --dport 1194 -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -i br101 -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -o br101 -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -d 192.168.101.2/32 -p udp -m udp --dport 1194 -j ACCEPT 

Nova-network should definately not forward all traffic from the bridges since it's in the other tenants networks too. It should be something like
-A nova-network-FORWARD -i br100 -o $external_interface -j ACCEPT 
-A nova-network-FORWARD -i br100  -j DROP 

Other services (metadata) should however be considered, so that traffic isn't dropped. The ouput rule is also way too liberal, since it is processed before the next bridge's input rule.
title: Nova-network bridges traffic between tenant VLANs by default

comments.content: I'm not totally sure why this is an issue. This layer3 traffic is blocked by security group rules. This allows tenants to create rules that can allow traffic from other tenants. Without it there is no way to allow traffic from another tenants vms.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~vishvananda

comments.content:
Well I a few things that are problematic with this. First of all, tenants should be separated if you use VLANs. I see that it is expected by tenants that nobody can get into their network (be it L2 or L3). Security group rules help, but one can get sloppy with them. If tenants need to communicate with each other, they can communicate via external IPs. As I see it, other tenants are "external" to the network, and should use the same mechanisms of accessing the network as anybody else.

The second thing is that admins have an expectation that the users are separated from the internal admin networks. Now all users have direct access to any internal networks one might have. The problem can be mitigated, but users should definately not have easy access to admin networks.

I guess much of the issue goes away with Quantum, but for Essex with nova-network I would argue that this is a problem.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~kalle-happonen
